Now before we get to the fun stuff, just a couple notes about this avatar:


- If I ever get in the way you can just click that little 'X' in the upper left to hide me. To bring me back click on "Continue Conversation" over on the far left sidebar.

- You can also click the back button to review something or click the "Manage Coach" button to reset the entire tutorial.

- Finally, this avatar is NOT a chatbot. Unfortunately, there's no way for you to ask it questions along the way.

While this avatar can't answer your questions, the human version of Natalie probably can. 

Learning new software on top of learning how to manage your money can be A LOT, so if you ever need some in-person support, click here to schedule 1-on-1 time.
highlight: zoom_link

Ok, so here's an overview of what we'll be covering:

1. Budget Tour & Setup
2. Account Tour & Setup 
3. Budgeting Skills
4. How to Add Transactions
5. Adding Credit Card Account(s)

Database - can keep responses and reference later on; not all questions need the database capture. The second line of the response selected is the database code. If not planning to reference answer later or drive flow based on response in another section, don't need second line.

<<Accounts>> / <<Budget>>

This aligns the avatar with which screen the user should be on. If a user goes to the Budget at a step where the avatar flow has <<Accounts>>, or if the user goes to an Account while the avatar is on Budget, the user will see the following message:

 Please navigate to the Accounts {Budget} to continue our conversation (please select an account).

Please Note: There needs to be a blank line between the reference to Accounts/Budget and the text shown in the avatar window.
Trusting Your Numbers

One of the complexities for users with a zero-based budgeting software is the due diligence to ensure the account balances in MyBudgetCoach match the account balances in the financial institution. 

A difficult part of having the accounts match is ensuring the starting balance set by the user at the time the accounts are added are accurate. For checking accounts, some banks include pending transactions in the Current Balance. If the starting balance includes pending transactions, then when the transactions are added, they will be double counted. For credit cards, the Current Balance doesn't include pending transactions, so this is not an issue. 

Coach can consider consulting Coach Trainers to add a flow for verifying starting balance.

What kind of device?

Consider asking a user what type of device they are using. If using a computer, the current language for how to access options works. If using a tablet, somethings are different (tap versus hover; double click versus single click...). Can utilize the IF syntax to adjust the response in a box where overviewing how to use software dependent on the device the user has.

Buttons default to 'Next' if no text is added on line. Button text can be short, or long (even two sentences) and include emojis. If have multiple lines due to a question, can program button text for each line.
Additional Conversations
Simple FIN

MyBudgetCoach has a direct import option. A coach can either walk through in detail how to complete this, or they can create a separate conversation for if a user to click through at a later point if interested.

Accounts can be linked at any time, so if added manually, can then link for direct import later on.

Linking direct import immediately can be helpful as SimpleFIN's connection will automatically set the starting balance. But the process takes some time and for a new user, they may want to make progress on the software itself and not spend 10-15 minutes just setting up direct import. 

Could always recommend they delete prior accounts, and add new ones once SimpleFIN is linked. This first budget is just a test to get started. Set up real budget with your actual accounts and setting up.
Let's Do This! 💪💪
Ready to get started?
Budget Summary Overview
Sounds good

Sweet! Let's start with the budget. 

Your budget is your roadmap for your money. 

It’s not a rigid, scary thing you have to follow or else. It’s just a guide to help you remember your goals and priorities when you’re making financial decisions. 

But before we dive into actually building your budget, let’s get to know the software a bit.

<<Budget>>

 This is the budget screen. Here you can see your current month's budget, but also past and future months' budgets.

Let's start at the top and work our way down.
For sure!

<<Budget>>

One of the cool things about MyBudgetCoach is that you can actually see up to 6 months at a time! (assuming you have a big enough screen). Wanna test it out?
move_to: calendar_icons

<<Budget>>

Right up here you'll see all your options. Go ahead and select the 3rd icon.
Got it

<<Budget>>

Look at that! Three months' worth of budgets. 

Want to switch which months you're seeing? No problem. 

Click which months you'd like to look at by using this purple selection.
move_to: months_band

<<Budget>>

Below the current month you'll see a "To Budget" number.

This is the MAIN number you're going to be focusing on as you budget.

If you click it you'll get some extra options.
move_to: budget_header
Sounds good!

<<Budget>>

Did you click on that purple "To Budget" number? 

This is a bit of a sneak peek into some of the different ways to move money around in your budget. 

Don't worry. We'll be covering the ACTUAL budgeting process later. (Gotta build the foundation before you move into the house 😜)

<<Budget>>

Oh, and if you want to collapse the budget header area to give yourself a bit more room, you can totally do that. 

Just hover over the month at the top of the budget summary and you'll see two little arrows pop up on the left. 

Click those to collapse the summary view so you're only seeing the "To Budget" amount. 

You can expand it back out by repeating the process.

<<Budget>>

The last part of this budget header we want to take a look at is the extra options behind those three little dots over on the right. 

Selecting these dots will give you some quick budgeting actions. 

You'll need to build up some history with the app for a couple of the options, but if you ever want to clear out all your budgeted amounts, the "Set budgets to zero" option is for you.
So far so good!

<<Budget>>

Feeling good so far?

If so, let's move on and learn a bit about the next section of your budget.
Budget Table Overview
Got it

<<Budget>>

This is the budget table. 

It's kind of like a digital envelope system only instead of envelopes for your money, we'll be using categories.

<<Budget>>

This is the category column where you can create a structure for your budget that makes sense to you. We'll talk a little bit more about what that looks like in a bit.
Got it

<<Budget>>

The next column is your Budgeted column. This is where you actually budget your dollars.

<<Budget>>

Next is the spent column which shows you what you've actually spent out of your budget.

<<Budget>>

And finally is the Balance column. 

This shows you how much you have left to spend in each category. 

If it's negative and red it means you've overspent. An amount in black is what you have available.
Good to know

<<Budget>>

PRO-TIP: When you have overspending you'll most likely want to move some money around, reallocating your dollars to cover it. This way you don't risk over drafting your account or adding debt.

<<Budget>>

A couple more things to note with the budget table: 

- Clicking on the 3 dots to the right of "Category" will give you the option to expand and collapse your category groups, as well as reveal any hidden categories you may have. 

- Hovering over any categories or category groups will give you additional options as well...let's take a look.
Got it

<<Budget>>

The Category Groups have a gray background and are where you can, well, group similar categories. 

By hovering over the group name you can add more categories, as well as rename, delete, and hide them. 

To add a new category group you'll click the "Add Group" button at the bottom
Very cool!

<<Budget>>

You may also have noticed when you hover over a category (those are the ones with the white background) you'll see a little note icon. That's because you can make notes for each category. This can be super helpful for keeping track of due dates and amounts as well as savings targets.
Let's keep going!

<<Budget>>

Phew! I know that was a lot, but NOW we get to jump into the good stuff. 

Ready?
Bring it!

<<Budget>>

So now that we know how the app works it’s time to start having some fun.
Budget Setup
Makes sense

<<Budget>>

I like to think of your budget like a roadmap for your money. 

You've got a goal for what you want to achieve – your destination –  then you start plotting out the route you want to take to get there – your budget.

<<Budget>>

Some people like a more scenic route, while others like to barrel through and get there as soon as possible. 

Your budget is meant to reflect your personal preferences so you'll not just use it, but actually ENJOY using it.

Submit
primary_goal = [user_input]

<<Budget>>

Before we can effectively map out our route, it helps to have a destination in mind. 

So tell me: What is ONE goal you're hoping this budget can help you achieve?
For sure! I'm super pumped!

<<Budget>>

Awesome goal! 

Now that you've got a "destination" in mind you should also have a bit more momentum and awareness for actually building things out.

<<Budget>>

Sweet! 

Let's start with your budget structure first. This is basically how you're going to organize your categories.
Got it. Let's get to it.

<<Budget>>

There are a few popular options I’ll walk you through but just remember:

 It’s YOUR budget and it’s ok to set it up in whatever way works for you.

 Nothing we do is permanent. You can always tweak and adjust as you go. In fact I encourage you to do just that.

<<Budget>>

Ok, let’s think back for a sec to the idea of a roadmap. 

Depending on your personality and your destination (ie your goals) you may want turn by turn instructions, or you might be good with more general directions. 

This could be reflected in a lot of ways in your budget, but we're going to start with your category groups. 

Remember these are the collapsable groups with a gray background that have other categories within them.
Sounds good

<<Budget>>

There are a few general structures we can start with:

- Needs vs Wants
- Monthly vs Non-monthly
- Paycheck to Paycheck

Let me briefly explain each and then you can decide which you think will work best for you.

<<Budget>>

With a Needs vs Wants budget your categories will fall into one of those 2 groups, making it easy to know that you've got your essentials covered.
Makes sense

<<Budget>>

A Monthly vs Non-monthly budget structure lets you break out your expenses in an easy to follow and timely flow so you can make sure not to get caught off guard by future expenses.
Got it

<<Budget>>

Finally, a Paycheck to Paycheck budget is structured to group your expenses per paycheck so you can quickly break the paycheck-to-paycheck cycle and start building your savings or paying off debt more quickly.

<<Budget>>

You'll notice a few common categories have been added already, but I want you to practice customizing things yourself. 

So go ahead and add a few categories you know you'll need. 

Also, while you can use the Notes, you might find it helpful to add due dates directly to your category for an easy at-a-glance reference.

<<Budget>>

Having fun yet? One of my favorite ways to make budgeting fun is to customize my categories in silly ways that motivate me. 

For example I use the celebrate emoji 🥳 for my fun money category to remind me that anything goes for those dollars. 

You might notice I also like to use more abundant language for my categories, so instead of an Emergency Fund, I call it an Opportunity Fund. (with the money bag emoji 💰)

<<Budget>>

One more thing. MyBudgetCoach is built on the premise of zero-based budgeting. 

I'll explain a bit more about this when we actually start budgeting, but for now just know the idea is to assign every dollar a job. 

That means we not only need to budget for our current expenses, but for our FUTURE spending...ie, savings.
Ah, gotcha

<<Budget>>

Didja catch that? Savings is actually just future spending. So we definitely want to add it to the budget.
Got it

<<Budget>>

PRO-TIP: Take a few minutes to brainstorm what sort of Sinking Funds you might want to save for, and add them to your budget now so you can be prepared for them later.
Tell me

<<Budget>>

Ok, now you should have a pretty well structured budget with some relevant categories for you. I've got just one more thing to throw at you as far as the budget goes...
Ah, ok

<<Budget>>

Remember that  "your budget is a roadmap" analogy I used? 

Well, there's one more aspect to think about – how granular do you want your budget to be?

Your level of granularity is basically kinda like the difference between using an old school road map or a modern GPS system to guide you. 

If you're the type who likes turn-by-turn directions, you might want a more granular approach to see exactly where every dollar is going. 

For example, instead of a general "Utilities" category, you'd have each utility broken out into its own category (ie. "Phone", "Internet", "Gas", "Electric", etc.).

<<Budget>>

So take a sec to look back at your categories and make sure they reflect the level of granularity you want. Make any changes you'd like before moving on.

NOTE: If you're planning to budget by paycheck, I'd suggest a more granular approach so you can see exactly when each of your expenses is due so you know which paycheck they'll be coming out of.
Yeah I am!

<<Budget>>

AWESOME!!! You. Are. A. Rockstar!

<<Budget>>

Now, you've got your budget set up, but you can't actually start using it until you have some money to budget. 

So let's head over to the Accounts section now and get that all set up.

<<Budget>>

Seriously, the budget setup is probably the MOST important step because it's the one that brings more awareness into what you're spending your money on...and more importantly, what you WANT to be spending it on.
Account Setup Process

<<Accounts>>

This is the accounts section of your budget. 

This is where you're going to be actually tracking your spending and monitoring your account balances so you can make sure your budget is based on your real numbers.

<<Accounts>>

And boom! First account added. Nice job! 

Now go ahead and repeat that process for any other accounts. 

(Remember, we're holding off on credit cards for right now) 

Once you're done, we'll move on to adding transactions.

<<Accounts>>

Next, you'll want to select "Create Local Account" and go ahead and give it a name, choose which type it is, and enter the starting balance. 

For example, if you're adding your primary checking account you may call it "Main Checking", choose the "For Budget: Checking" type, and add whatever your current balance is. 

Then select the "Create" button.

<<Accounts>>

Ready? Awesome! Let's start adding accounts! (Oh, and let's just stick with your checking and savings accounts for now. We'll deal with credit cards later on.) 

Go ahead and select "+Add Account"
All set

<<Accounts>>

First thing's first, you need to know which accounts you're going to add, and what the current balances are. 

Go ahead and log into your bank accounts and grab the latest data (including any transactions that haven't cleared yet). Then come back to me when you've got the info.

<<Accounts>>

Alright, let's add some money!

<<Accounts>>

Ok, let's start with a little personalization. 

Just like you can rename your budget categories, you can rename your budget itself. Click here and rename your budget to whatever you want. 

If you plan to have multiple budgets or start fresh each year, you may want to include the date in your budget name.

<<Accounts>>

One thing to keep in mind when it comes to your accounts is that you want your budget to reflect reality. 

Whatever happens with your money in the real world you want reflected in your budget. 

If it's not, you can't trust your numbers and therefore you can't trust your budget. Make sense?
move_to: budget_name
move_to: add_account
Add Transaction
Let's do it!

<<Accounts>>

Alright! Let's get into the weeds and learn how to add transactions.

<<Accounts>>

I know learning new software is a lot so if you need a break, this is a good stopping point. 

Then when you're ready to move on, we'll dive into the ACTUAL act of budgeting.
I've got this!

<<Accounts>>

And that's the Accounts screen! Congrats! You're making massive progress.

<<Accounts>>

Finally, these 3 dots will give you even more options. 

Most are self-explanatory, and the ones that aren't, we'll deal with later.

<<Accounts>>

This is the "Split/Toggle" button. If you have any split transactions, this button will expand or collapse them.

<<Accounts>>

This is the "Search" bar. As you start to type, your transactions will automagically filter based on what you're typing.

<<Accounts>>

Ok, just a few more things to cover.
Good to know

<<Accounts>>

There are also "undo" and "redo" buttons to help you out. These are available on the Budget screen as well. 

Just keep in mind these buttons work across the app to undo or redo the most recent action, regardless of which screen you did it on. 

So if you just finished budgeting to zero on the budgets screen by adding $20 to groceries, then swapped over to the Accounts screen and hit the undo button, it's going to undo that $20 budgeted to groceries.

<<Accounts>>

This is the "Filter" button and it lets you filter the transactions you're seeing based on whatever criteria you give it (date, payee, category, etc.)

<<Accounts>>

This is the "Import" button and it'll let you upload a file of transactions you exported from your bank.

<<Accounts>>

Now before we leave the Accounts screen, there are a few more things I want to point out.

<<Accounts>>

Once you select the transaction, you'll notice some purple text with "1 transaction" appears. 

Click it to get a whole bunch of options, including "Delete." 

Go ahead and select delete to remove this transaction. Then repeat the process to delete the other one as well.
Transaction selected

<<Accounts>>

Now that you've added a couple transactions, and know how everything works, we can go ahead and delete them so they don't confuse you later. 

Hover over on the left side of the date to un-hide a little box. 

Select the box to select the entire transaction.
Got it

<<Accounts>>

One more thing before we move on... See that little white circle with the checkmark in it? 

That means the transactions we just added aren't cleared (ie. they're not showing up in your real life account just yet). 

Let's pretend you just deposited the Bonus and it's IS showing up in your account. Go ahead and click that circle to make it green. That means it HAS cleared. 

But let's say you wrote a check for your groceries and it hasn't posted yet. We'll just leave it as uncleared until it does.
Grocery expense added

<<Accounts>>

 If you have a note to add, feel free, otherwise we're jumping ahead to the "Category" field and selecting whatever you named your Food budget. 

Then enter in an optimistic amount in the "Payment" box (Let's manifest the cost of groceries coming down this time 😜) and hit enter.

<<Accounts>>

In the future when you're done, just click cancel to get rid of the add transaction window. 

But right now we want to practice recording an outflow as well. 

So go ahead and choose today's date again. 

Make up a Payee. Let's try to think of a real expense you have so we can more easily match it up with a category you have in your budget. 

Maybe "Groceries" or the name of the store you shop at.
Awesome! What's next?

<<Accounts>>

Congrats! You've added your first transaction!
I went big! Show me the money Universe!

<<Accounts>>

Go ahead and enter in whatever number you want. (The bigger the better! We're manifesting here. 🤑)

Click the "Add" button to finish up.

<<Accounts>>

Now we're in the "Category" section. 

This is where you're going to decide where this money belongs in your budget. 

Since this is an inflow, we're gonna choose "Income". Then advance to the "Deposit" side of the ledger (that's either "tab tab" or just click it )
It's true...I AM awesome

<<Accounts>>

Now you should find yourself in the "Notes" field. 

This isn't a necessary field to fill out but maybe you want to know exactly what that Bonus was for. Let's go ahead and type in "Because I'm awesome" and hit that tab key again (or click...you know the routine).
Manifesting energy enabled

<<Accounts>>

This field represents either where the money went or where it came from. 

How about we manifest some positive energy and add an inflow to start? 

Let's say you just got a nice bonus at work. Type "Bonus" in the Payee field and hit the Tab key to jump to the next field (or you can click if you're more of a mouse person)

<<Accounts>>

So let's practice adding a couple transactions to get the feel of things. 

Go ahead and click  "+Add New." 

You'll see the date field automatically pop open. Just choose today's date and either tap the next field, "Payee" or hit the Tab key to advance.
Got it

<<Accounts>>

Now, a little heads up about the language MyBudgetCoach uses when it comes to checking account transactions: "payments" DECREASE your balance whereas "deposits" INCREASE it. 

Basically, "payments" represent outflows and "deposits" represent inflows.

<<Accounts>>

First, go ahead and select your checking account. We'll work in there for now.

Let's do this!

Hey hey! Congrats on making it this far! 

You've done a TON of work setting everything up, but there's one more step left. And it's the best step because it's kinda fun... 

NOW you get to go tell your money what you want it to do for you.

Head back over to the Budget screen and let's take a look at what's different now that we have some money.
It matches. We're good.

<<Budget>>

First, you should see the "To Budget" number isn't zero anymore. 

It SHOULD match the amount you have available across your accounts. If it doesn't, make sure you've deleted out those test transactions we created.

<<Budget>>

Now, before we jump straight into assigning your dollars, I want to explain a little bit about this "To Budget" number. 

I want you to think of it like a big bucket. MyBudgetCoach is account agnostic – it doesn't care WHERE your money is, it collects it into one big bucket for you to assign.
Do tell...

<<Budget>>

If you only have a one account, it doesn't really matter, but if you have separate checking and savings accounts or multiple of each, things can get kind of confusing when it comes time to pay the bills.
So how do I work around that?

<<Budget>>

Basically, since you're budgeting ALL your dollars (the goal is always to get the "To Budget" number to 0), that means those savings dollars are mixed in with the checking dollars. 

Not a problem if you reflect that in your budget (I'll explain how in a minute), but just know the more accounts you have the greater your risk of accidentally budgeting savings dollars to spending goals.

<<Budget>>

If you want to make sure your savings dollars are budgeted to savings categories, the best way to handle this is to create category GROUPS that represent the different savings accounts. 

Let's look at a simple example with a checking and savings account. 

Say you want to spend out of the checking account, and set money aside into the savings account for unexpected or upcoming expenses.

<<Budget>>

Remember that "Sinking Funds" category group we created earlier? 

That's exactly what this account is for...building up those sinking funds.

So you budget those savings then transfer the money into your savings account and then check that your new savings account balance matches the balance in your Sinking Funds category group. 

If it does, great! 

If it doesn't you either need to move money around in your budget until it does, or transfer money into that savings account to reflect the amount in your budget. Good?

<<Budget>>

Ok, so let's start planning! There are a few ways to actually budget your dollars:

- First, you can just click in the "Budgeted" section next to a category and type in an amount.
- Second, you can click the "To Budget" number and move money to a category via the dropdown
- Third, you can select the amount under the "Balance" column of a category and choose to transfer budgeted funds to another category.

<<Budget>>

Now, before I let you loose to go assign all your dollars I want you to take a sec and think about what those dollars need to do BEFORE you get paid again. 

Don't worry about prior expenses or bills that have already been paid this month, just look ahead to what needs to be budgeted for RIGHT NOW. 

What bills are due before your next payday? 
How much will you need for groceries and gas? 
Any planned outings or holidays? 

The FIRST step is to cover that spending.

<<Budget>>

Ok great! 

Now you get to prioritize how you want to allocate those extra dollars. 

Typically I advise my clients to use these funds to start building out their sinking funds until you have a safety buffer you feel comfortable with. 

But if you have a primary goal like debt payoff or a certain savings target, you can also assign those funds there. 

You could also budget ahead to make sure future bills are covered; but be careful doing that if you don't have enough in your sinking funds, since it's usually the unexpected expenses that throw us off and lead to debt. 

Go ahead and budget to zero now

<<Budget>>

Ok, good to know. 

If you've budgeted all your dollars to zero and can't cover your expenses until you get paid again, you have a few options. 

First is to evaluate your expenses to see if there's anything you can cut or reassign. Maybe you can cancel Netflix for the month or try to batch cook to save on groceries. 

If you're already at bare bones with nowhere to cut, you may be able to call companies and see about getting your payment due dates adjusted so you can budget it after you get paid again. 

The other option is to accept the debt as you work to bring your spending below your income. We'll discuss how to handle your debt when we talk about credit cards. If this is where you're at, just budget to 0 for now. 
PSA: DO NOT BUDGET MONEY YOU DON'T HAVE.
I like being intentional with my money

<<Budget>>

Alright! Congrats on budgeting to zero! 

Ya know, you've actually just done probably the hardest part of the entire process... you made decisions! 

It's not always easy to prioritize, so props for getting it done. 

And rest easy knowing that you can always change your mind. 

The reason we want to make decisions NOW is so that we can practice being intentional with our money. 

So even if we need to make adjustments, we know they're in alignment with our values because we're being intentional about them.

<<Budget>>

Ok, before we wrap things up I just want to explain what it means if you see a negative (red) number in the "Balance" column.

<<Budget>>

Seeing red in your "Balance" column means you've overspent that category. 

Whether you didn't budget enough for the electric bill this month or that vet bill cost more than you've been able to save so far, you spent more than you had budgeted. 

To fix it, you simply need to budget more dollars to that category.

<<Budget>>

Incidentally, if you ever notice a negative red number for your "To Budget" number, that means you've over-budgeted.

You'll need to reduce your budget by that amount to get back to zero.

<<Budget>>

I call this playing Whack-a-Mole.

 Whenever you see red in your budget, you need to whack it just like the moles that pop up in the game.

<<Budget>>

To WAM your overspending, just click on the red number in the "Balance" column and select "Cover overspending". 

From there you'll have the option to select which category you want to move money from in order to cover the overspending. 

You DO have the option to carry a negative balance forward, but there's very few times that's a good idea.
Ok, but what if I don't have a choice?

<<Budget>>

Typically I only have clients want to do this with reimbursed expenses, which kind of makes sense. 

But at the same time, that money is gone NOW. So it makes more sense to cover that spending and then allocate the reimbursed dollars the same as any other income when you receive it.

<<Budget>>

If you can't cover the overspending then it becomes debt, and we'll deal with that when we get into credit cards. 

Which is where we're heading next!

<<Budget>>

The next step will depend on if you still have dollars left to assign or not.
I still have money in "To Budget"
I don't have enough money
Ok, I'm at 0

<<Budget>>

Now, ready to talk credit cards?
I don't use credit cards
I think so?

Ok! Let's add one more account to capture your total expenses.

<<Accounts>>

Select "+Add Account", click "Create Local Account."

Name your account, select a Type of "For Budget: Credit Card", and then enter the current balance of that account.

<<Budget>>

You'll want to plan on Budgeting dollars to make a payment of at least your minimum payment for each account.

<<Accounts>>

Ok! Let's go ahead and add the credit card account you use the most often of your remaining accounts.

<<Accounts>>

Now click "Create Local Account." Name your account, select a Type of 'For Budget: Credit Card' and then enter the current balance of that account.

<<Accounts>>

Awesome! That wraps up adding accounts. Now let's move on and learn how to add transactions to a credit card account.

<<Accounts>>

Now click "Create Local Account." Name your account, select a Type of 'For Budget: Credit Card' and then enter the current balance of that account.

Now, because you'll be carrying some debt over to next month, there are a few additional steps we'll walk through to make sure MyBudgetCoach works for you.

<<Accounts>>

<<Budget>>

Now, because you can pay the balance in-full, and you have a credit card category with a 'Balance' = 0, moving forward with your MyBudgetCoach use, you'll be funding your categories outside of the credit card category. 

If you aren't accumulating any debt and cover any overspent categories, then your credit card payment will be equal to your current balance.

For the credit card account(s) you added, are there any that you plan to pay off the current balance at the end of this month?

Please note, by 'current balance' I am referring to the balance you entered when you added the account. This is not the statement balance, which is a balance as of an earlier date.
You can complete the 'Calculate Credit Card Payment' conversation at any time to assist in determining what your credit card payment should be.

<<Budget>>

Ok, don't worry! Give yourself some grace and remember, reducing your debt is a journey and takes dedication. 

You've already started working toward your goal by creating a budget and working through this conversation to learn more!
Got it

<<Budget>>

If you have more than one credit card account, you'll need to complete the following steps for each account.

<<Budget>>

Step 1 is to create a Category Group called 'Credit Cards.' Under that Category Group, you'll add a Category for each of the credit card account(s) you added.

Let me add this for you as a starting point...

<<Budget>>

OK! Step 1 done. 

Now if you scroll down to the bottom of your budget table you'll find the Credit Card category group. Go ahead and  rename the newly created category to your specific credit card account name.

create_category_group: Credit Cards
create_category: Credit Cards: Credit Card Account

<<Accounts>>

The first transaction should be the transaction that was added when you first added the account. You should see an amount in the 'Payment' column that equals the balance on the day you added the account.

<<Accounts>>

Now that we've created the category on the Budget for the Credit Card Account, we're going to change the Category from 'Starting Balance' to the newly created category for your Credit Card Account.
Great work! Now, lets go back to the Budget and see what happened with the 'Spent' and 'Balance' columns in the Credit Card Account category.

<<Budget>>

Scroll down to the credit card category of the account you just updated. Now the 'Spent' column is a negative number that equals your balance you entered previously.

<<Budget>>

Since the 'Budgeted' column for the category is 0, the 'Balance' is a negative red number and is equal to 'Spent.'
highlight: spent_column

<<Budget>>

The last step, Step 3, is to complete the actions for how you want MyBudgetCoach to handle the debt associated with the credit card. 

You have some options, so let me ask you a quick question so I can give you the right guidance.

<<Budget>>

Good for you! Props for managing your debt. Not a lot of people with a credit card balance have the cash flow to pay it in-full at any time.

<<Budget>>

So, to fund your balance you'll want to enter the amount of your credit card balance in the Budgeted column of your newly created credit card category. 

This will update the 'Balance' to be 0 since you budgeted dollars to equal the current balance of the credit card.

<<Budget>>

When you Budget the dollars, the purple number at the top of the Budget Summary in the 'To Budget' goes down.

<<Budget>>

You can now confidently budget the rest of your available dollars to your remaining categories, until your 'To Budget' number is 0. 

If you want to learn more about this process, look for the 'Make To Budget Equal to 0' conversation to work through when you're done here.

<<Budget>>

First, we need to allow the remaining balance you don't pay off this current month, to continue to future months, since your credit card company will continue to have that balance carry over until you pay it off.

<<Budget>>

MyBudgetCoach has a unique feature called 'Rollover overspending.' This option allows a user to have the debt continue into future months, instead of paying off this month, so you can pay it off overtime.

<<Budget>>

Selecting the 'Rollover overspending' option increases your 'To Budget' number in the current month, since the debt has now been rolled over to future months.

<<Budget>>

Select the negative amount in red text in the Balance column of your Credit Card Account Category. Within the option menu that comes up, select the 'Rollover overspending' option.

To see the system roll the debt over to a future month, select the option in the top left to show two months at a time by selecting the 2nd calendar icon.

<<Budget>>

Did you notice that little arrow to the right of the amount in the Balance column? 

That's how MyBudgetCoach lets you know that you've rolled over the overspending for future months. 

This option will stay turned on for all future months, unless you select to 'Remove overspending rollover.'

<<Budget>>

When you budget to this category in the future it reduces the debt immediately. 

You'll still have to submit a payment through your credit card account, but you can see your progress in the category right away.

<<Budget>>

To handle interest applied to your credit card account(s), you'd categorize that transaction to the Category of your Credit Card Account, just like how you updated the Starting Balance category.

<<Budget>>

Credit Cards can be complex, especially if you have more than one. So if you need any additional help I'm available for a one-on-one call to help answer any questions you may have.

<<Accounts>>

Something important to note is that the terminology for inflows and outflows for a credit card account are the opposite of a bank account. 

For your credit card account Payments (outflows) INCREASE the balance, and Deposits (inflows) DECREASE the balance.

<<Accounts>>

Ok, let's practice adding a couple transactions. Go ahead and select your primary credit card account.

<<Accounts>>

Select '+ Add New,' select today's date and enter a Payee of 'Cell Phone Company.'

<<Accounts>>

Select the applicable category and enter a Payment amount of 100 and click 'Add.'

<<Accounts>>

Now let's add a transaction for a credit card payment. Credit Card payments are Transfers and entered as a Deposit.
Ok, cool

<<Accounts>>

You'll notice the credit card balance (the red negative number over on the top left under your Account name) has increased by 100.

You can also see this in your actual register if you select the 3 vertical dots on the far right and select "Show running balance"

<<Accounts>>

Select '+ Add New,' select today's date, and for the Payee, select 'Make Transfer.' 

Within the 'Transfer To/From' list of accounts, select your checking account.

<<Accounts>>

The Category field is now populated with Transfer. 

Enter 100 in the 'Deposit' field, since this is a payment to reduce the credit card balance, and select 'Add.'

<<Accounts>>

Now, let's jump over to the checking account.

<<Accounts>>

Since you selected 'Make Transfer' as the Payee in your credit card account, this automatically added a transaction to your checking account as well.

<<Accounts>>

Please note that the credit card payment is an outflow in the Payment column for the checking account, but an inflow in the Deposit column for the credit card. 

This is because your payment reduces a negative balance (Deposit) in the credit card account and reduces the positive balance (Payment) in the checking account.

<<Accounts>>

And there ya go! Congrats on creating transactions for both accounts!

<<Accounts>>

Before we move to the next step, let's go ahead and delete those two credit card transactions you added.

<<Accounts>>

Navigate back to your main credit card account and select each of the two transactions using the box to the left of the date. Then select the link named '2 transactions' to the right of the search bar and choose 'Delete.'

<<Accounts>>

Awesome! Direct Import within MyBudgetCoach has some great benefits. 

For example, the starting balance for linked accounts is automatically set and the system includes three prior days worth of transactions to get you started.

<<Accounts>>

Direct Import is a convenient way to add transactions without having to manually upload them yourself. 

Each time you log in, the system will automatically have added your recent transactions.

<<Accounts>>

MyBudgetCoach uses machine learning, so as you continue to use the system, it will automatically apply proposed categories to new transactions. 

Basically it'll know all those Kroger purchases should be categorized as Groceries. 

You'll still want to double check things, especially for stores that you tend to split transactions at (I'm looking at you Target). But overall, you should have less work to do over time when it comes to categorizing transactions.

<<Accounts>>

For security purposes, MyBudgetCoach has partnered with a third-party service, SimpleFIN, to link your accounts. 

SimpleFIN uses a well-established connection software called 'MX' to connect your bank account financial institutions to SimpleFIN.

<<Accounts>>

To connect SimpleFIN to MyBudgetCoach, there is a one-time code produced by SimpleFIN to enter into MyBudgetCoach. 

The accounts you link in SimpleFIN will then become available to link to already existing accounts within MyBudgetCoach to start Direct Import.

<<Accounts>>

Please note SimpleFIN does have a small additional fee: $1.50 per month, or $15 per year (not including tax, if applicable). 

This is paid separately from your MyBudgetCoach subscription and is paid through SimpleFIN, not within MyBudgetCoach.
I'm good, thanks!

Awesome! For this to work, you just want to be sure your columns are organized like this:

Date / Payee / Notes / Category (blank) / Amount

The amount can either be one column, or split into separate columns, one for Payments and one for Deposits.

MyBudgetCoach can also split up the amount column into two separate columns by splitting the positive and negative values.

<<Accounts>>

Once you have your data organized the correct way, use the 'Import' button to select your csv file to upload. 

Follow along the MyBudgetCoach screen to select the appropriate column in your csv file to map to the correct MyBudgetCoach field.

<<Accounts>>

Thanks for selecting the Import Transaction Options conversation!

In this conversation, we'll walk through the different methods for adding transactions into MyBudgetCoach.

When it comes to importing transactions you've got three options:

Option 1: Adding transactions manually (the Introduction conversation walked you through this process),

Option 2: Direct Import. We'll use a third-party bank connection software, SimpleFIN, to pull in your transactions automagically. Once it's all setup you'll just select 'Sync' transactions and 'BAM' they're all automatically brought into MyBudgetCoach for each of your accounts.

Option 3: Bulk Import. This is where we'll upload exports of transactions from your bank to MyBudgetCoach in order to add transactions in bulk for each account.

Thanks for selecting the Make 'To Budget' Equal to 0 conversation!

When it comes to your Budget, the 'To Budget' number is super important.

If it's positive, you've got dollars left that need a job. If it's negative, you've over budgeted and need to take money back. 

But if it's 0, you've successfully balanced your budget! Yay! 

This conversation will guide you through how to update the 'To Budget' amount.

<<Budget>>

Let's start by reviewing the 'Balance' amount in your non-Credit Card categories. 

If the 'Balance' is greater than 0, consider whether the amount you entered in the Budget column is required now (before you get paid again) or if it can wait.

<<Budget>>

You can move money around between categories, or even back to the 'To Budget' number, by selecting the amount in the 'Balance' column. 

Just make sure you've set aside enough money in the 'Balance' for categories that have upcoming expenses you need to pay from your checking account.

When you've moved money around to cover those upcoming expenses, come back to continue.

No; The 'To Budget' is now a positive purple amount.

When reviewing your Credit Card account transactions, locate (or add) the row for the payment and adjust the Payee by selecting 'Make Transfer.' Within the 'Transfer To/From' list of accounts, select your checking account.

<<Accounts>>

The Category field is now populated with Transfer. 

The amount in the 'Deposit' column, equal to the payment amount, reduces the credit card balance. Select Add.

<<Accounts>>

Now let's jump over to the checking account.

<<Accounts>>

Since you selected 'Make Transfer' as the Payee in your credit card account, this automatically added a transaction to your checking account as well. 

Double check if a duplicate Payment transaction exists on your account. If there is one, delete it so the transaction with the 'Transfer' is the only payment transaction.

<<Accounts>>

Please note that the 'Payment' field is populated for the checking account, which reduces the balance. 

However, the credit card account has the Deposit field populated because an inflow to a negative balance reduces the negative balance.
